contentrichtext.text: {{about|Monterey Jack cheese}} {{Infobox Cheese | name = Monterey Jack | image = | caption = Monterey Jack cheese mixed with peppers ([[Pepper jack cheese]] | othernames = | country = [[United States]], [[Mexico]] | regiontown = | region = | town = | source = [[Cow]]s | pasteurised = | texture = Semihard, creamy | fat = | protein = | dimensions = | weight = | aging = 1-6 months | certification = }} {{Cookbook|Monterey Jack Cheese}} '''Monterey Jack''' is an American semihard [[cheese]], customarily of pale yellow color, made using cow's milk. It is commonly sold by itself, or mixed with [[Colby (cheese)|Colby]] to make a marbled cheese known as [[Colby-Jack|Colby-Jack (or Co-Jack)]]. [[Cheddar cheese|Cheddar]]-Jack varieties are also available. In its earliest form, Monterey Jack was made by the [[Mexican people|Mexican]] [[Franciscan]] friars of [[Monterey, California]], during the 19th century. [[California]] businessman [[David Jack (businessman)|David Jack]] sold the cheese commercially. He produced a mild, white cheese, which came to be known as "Jack's Cheese", and eventually "Monterey Jack".<ref>{{cite book |title=Why do Pirates Love Parrots? An Imponderables Books|last= Feldman|first= David|authorlink= David Feldman (author)|year= 2006|publisher= Collins|location= New York|isbn= 0-06-088842-3|pages= 53â€“55}}</ref> A common misspelling is "Monterrey" Jack, presumably in confusion with the Mexican city of [[Monterrey]]. ==Aging== Most of the softer types generally found in American markets are [[cheese ripening|aged]] for only one month, while another variety of Monterey Jack is aged for up to six months. ==Variants== An aged version of this cheese, known as Dry Jack, can be churned or grated and used much like [[Parmesan cheese]]. Dry Jack was originally created by accident in 1915 when a San Francisco cheese wholesaler stored and forgot a number of wheels of fresh Jack cheese<ref name=sfgate />. When shipments of hard cheese from Europe were subsequently interrupted as [[World War I]] intensified, he rediscovered the stored Jack, which had become a well-aged hard cheese his customers found to be a good substitute for classic, aged hard cheeses such as [[Parmesan]].<ref name=sfgate>[http://articles.sfgate.com/1995-09-27/food/17816429_1_cheese-dry-jack-chefs Dry Monterey Jack Cheese: What's Old Is New Again]</ref> Another version called [[Pepper jack cheese|pepper jack]] mixes [[Chile pepper|hot peppers]] with Monterey Jack. Pepper jack is often used as an alternative cheese in dishes such as [[quesadilla]]s, but can be eaten with bread or crackers as a snack. Other versions are flavored with garlic or pesto, though they are less common than pepper jack. ==Health impact== Because of its low content of [[tyramine]], an organic compound thought to be associated with [[headaches]],<ref name=mednet>[http://www.medicinenet.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=56109 Headaches from Food: The Connection<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> it is frequently recommended as one of the few cheeses that is safe to eat for [[migraine]] sufferers.{{citation needed|date=February 2010}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mchsmuseum.com/cheese.html Monterey County Historical Society: Monterey Jack Cheese] *Brown, Robert Carlton (1955). [http://www.gutenberg.org/files/14293/14293-h/14293-h.htm#Page_37 Jack, California Jack and Monterey Jack], Chapter 4: "American Cheddars". In ''The Complete Book of Cheese''. Gramercy Publishing Company: New York, 1955. {{American cheeses}} [[Category:American cheeses]] [[Category:Cow's-milk cheeses]] [[Category:Cuisine of the Western United States]] [[Category:Cuisine of the Southern United States]] [[Category:Cuisine of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Tex-Mex cuisine]] [[Category:Agriculture in California]]
